comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [7 days later] The terrace of houses (see note) caught my eye and by chance matched one I had seen on Google Street view when trying to find the location of a Powerhouse Museum collection photo several months ago. Here is the Google street view of the terrace in Balmain at the corner of Punch Street and Fitzroy Avenue - maps.google.com.au/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&... Which means the "Cable Tram Trailer" is on Cockatoo Island ! Those look like temporary wooden rails - it is being loaded / unloaded on / from a barge. The Trailer looks new and very utilitarian, perhaps meant for industrial use.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
I'm no tram expert, but I can tell you this.

A cable tram consisted of two cars.  The leading grip or dummy car which carried the mecnanism for gripping the running cable underneath the roadway and a trailing or trailer car.

This car therefore was designed to be the second in a set of two.

The Sydney tram system was electrified in 1905 and cable cars were taken off the tracks.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: "On 22 May 1886, only six months after the opening of the first line in Melbourne, a line of about 1.5 miles length was opened by the New South Wales Government Railways from Milson's Point wharf, North Sydney, to Ridge Street. It was extended in 1893 a further 0.75 miles to Crow's Nest. On the city side of the harbour a second line, 2.5 miles long, was opened in 1894, extending from the western side of the city along King Street via William Street and King's Cross to Edgecliff. The engine house and car sheds were sited at Rushcutter's Bay. But Sydney, at the end of its patience with steam trams, had become sold on the idea of electrification. It abandoned plans for further cable lines from the city to Rozelle and Pyrmont, and the two existing lines were closed for conversion - at North Sydney on 11 February 1900, and the Edgecliff line on 15 January 1905." - source: Mind the Curve!: A History of the Cable Trams by John D. Keating, Melbourne University Press, 1971 (1970), p. 15. As only the Edgecliff line was operating after 1900, and the terrace was built in 1902, this photo must date between 1902 and 1905 - unless, that is, it was built for export? Maybe someone can find a photo of this cable tram trailer in use on the Edgecliff line? Or it could have been intended for the abandoned line to Rozelle and Pyrmont, and never saw service?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Of the Edgecliff line cable tram photos I have so far come across they are all of this design (have a look at this one: someone broke the glass plate negative, I do hope it wasn't done while digitising!) Our cable tram trailer does appear to be a very unique design. Are we sure it was a cable tram trailer and not a trailer for the new electric trams (did they have trailers?). Indeed beachcomberaustralia - tram expert required!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: I've found a double carriage electric tram at State Records and they are both electrified (@State Records NSW - note it is mis-titled "Double carriage cable tram car").

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [admiring pellethpoet's enthusiasm ! ] Yes this is a very plain, utilitarian example of a trailing car compared to the cable tram from the King St to Edgecliff line (PhM) - www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=207898&... . I am wondering if it a cable tram trailer at all - these captions are often unreliable. It resembles more the steam tram trailer's 'toastrack' layout, eg.- en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:RockhamptonSteamTrams1923.jpg . I cannot find in the online histories of Cockatoo Island (Biloela) any reference to a cable tram, or to the manufacture of tram rolling stock - it would have been loopy to build trams on an island! Which makes me think the trailer was coming TO the island for use on the limited railway network there, at a time when they were expanding infrastructure - otherwise it would have been easier to lift it with a large crane.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: I think we finally might be on track - unlike this poor tram!: 1 & 2

comment.author: 32801805@N04
comment._content: Its a 2 foot gauge tramway car built for the Burrinjuck Dam tramway. The tramway was used for the construction of the dam.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Aha! Thanks labasa2204. I knew someone would solve this one for us one day. It is a very narrow gauge isn't it? It's a wonder we didn't pick up on that. According to Wikipedia the Burrinjuck Dam began construction "in 1907. A narrow gauge (610mm) railway was constructed from the state system at Goondah to bring materials, etc, to the site." This ties in nicely with our known date of post-1902. Looks like the image will need to be renamed as it would have been a steam tram trailer, likely pulled behind Archie Here's Archie pulling a different tramcar along the narrow gauge

comment.author: 18901029@N00
comment._content: c 1907 also seems correct from the date for the Barren Jack tram photo which must be around 1908 from the image number - its number 50, and number 33 is dated 1908. With regards the original image, this photo taken from Cockatoo Island a few years earlier also has the row of terraces identified by beachcomberaustralia. The man in the main photo also bears some resemblance to my great grandfather, John Pratt, who was dockmaster at Cockatoo at that time.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Good find!  First Class car on the Glam Tram!

I bet that photo is also taken on Cockatoo Island - shiny, new and off the rails.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] On your records it should be "G" for Goondah, not "C" for "Coondah".  The car is named G[oondah] & B[arren] - J[ack] Railway.   Goondah is where the mainline junction was.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: I've just found a splendid photo of our passenger car in operation and fully peopled. The photo is dated 14.8.08 and is captioned "A train carries passengers on the Goondah-Burrinjuck narrow gauge railway". See Landmarks in Public Works: Engineers and Their Works in New South Wales, 1884-1914 edited by Lenore Coltheart & Don Fraser (Sydney : Hale & Iremonger, 1987), p. 133. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Don't forget to update the caption on this photo - no cables were involved in the tramway/narrow gauge railway.

comment._content: After a couple more comments on my scanned image of Archie I went to Google maps and started looking around the Goondah area. The right of way for the tram line is still shown on the maps if you zoom in far enough and you can make out the remains of the line on the satellite photos. Try starting here.
